description: Family kitchen wisdom aggregated by technique and category

tips.text: Use a candy thermometer - 235¬∞F is the soft ball stage. Don't guess!
On humid days, cook candy 2 degrees higher than the recipe calls for.
At high altitude, reduce the target temperature by 2¬∞F for every 1000 feet above sea level.
Never stir candy while it's boiling unless the recipe specifically says to - it causes crystallization.
Cool candy on a buttered surface or parchment paper, never wax paper - it can stick and melt.
Test yeast by dissolving it in warm water (105-110¬∞F) with a pinch of sugar. It should foam within 10 minutes.
Bread dough has risen enough when you poke it with your finger and the indent springs back slowly.
For a crispy crust, place a pan of water in the bottom of the oven while baking.
Let bread cool completely before slicing - cutting hot bread makes it gummy.
Brush the top of bread with butter immediately after removing from oven for a soft, golden crust.
Bring eggs and butter to room temperature before baking - they incorporate better and create fluffier cakes.
Don't open the oven door during the first 20 minutes of baking - the cold air can cause cakes to fall.
Test cake doneness by inserting a toothpick in the center - it should come out clean or with just a few moist crumbs.
Let cakes cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to finish cooling.
For level cake layers, wrap wet cloth strips around the outside of the pan while baking.
Chill cookie dough for at least 30 minutes before baking - it prevents spreading and improves flavor.
Use parchment paper or silicone mats - cookies bake more evenly and cleanup is easy.
Rotate cookie sheets halfway through baking for even browning.
Remove cookies from the oven when they look slightly underdone - they continue to bake on the hot sheet.
Keep everything cold when making pie crust - cold butter creates flaky layers.
Don't overwork pie dough - mix just until it comes together. Overworking makes it tough.
Brush pie crust with beaten egg for a golden, shiny finish.
Place a baking sheet under fruit pies to catch any drips.
Let fruit pies cool completely before cutting - the filling needs time to set.
Let meat rest after cooking - this allows juices to redistribute. Rest for 5 minutes per inch of thickness.
Pat meat dry before searing - moisture prevents proper browning.
Season meat generously with salt at least 40 minutes before cooking, or right before - anything in between draws out moisture.
Use a meat thermometer for perfect doneness every time. Don't guess!
Bring meat to room temperature before cooking for more even results.
For easy-peel hard boiled eggs, use eggs that are at least a week old.
Add a splash of vinegar to poaching water - it helps the egg whites hold together.
For fluffier scrambled eggs, add a splash of water instead of milk.
To separate eggs cleanly, crack them into your hand and let the whites slip through your fingers.
To prevent lumps in gravy, whisk the flour into cold liquid before adding to hot drippings.
Don't rush the roux - cook it for at least 2 minutes to remove the raw flour taste.
Strain lumpy gravy through a fine mesh sieve - no one will ever know!
Add a pat of cold butter at the end for a glossy, restaurant-quality sauce.
Salt vegetables after cooking, not before - salt draws out moisture and can make them soggy.
Roast vegetables at high heat (400¬∞F+) for better caramelization and flavor.
Don't crowd vegetables in the pan - give them space to brown properly.
Blanch green vegetables in boiling salted water, then shock in ice water to keep their bright color.
Start soups with saut√©ed onions, celery, and carrots (mirepoix) for the best flavor foundation.
Add a parmesan rind to simmering soup - it adds incredible depth of flavor.
Soups and stews taste better the next day - make them ahead when possible.
Skim fat from the top of soup by dragging a piece of bread or paper towel across the surface.
Test oil temperature by dropping in a small piece of bread - it should sizzle and turn golden in about 60 seconds at 350¬∞F.
Don't overcrowd the pan when frying - it drops the oil temperature and makes food soggy.
Drain fried foods on a wire rack, not paper towels - they stay crispier.
Let oil come back to temperature between batches for consistent results.
Read the entire recipe before starting - no surprises!
Mise en place - prepare and measure all ingredients before you start cooking.
Taste as you go and adjust seasonings throughout cooking.
Clean as you go - a tidy kitchen makes cooking more enjoyable.
When in doubt, add more garlic!
